title: How to Dry Chestnuts

steps.headline: Choose a spot exposed to open air.
steps.description: Pick a  spot with plenty of space, such as a countertop or table. The more air flowing through the spot, the faster the chestnuts will dry. Also, make sure the spot stays consistently around room temperature. A cool room, such as an attic or shed, is often a good choice.

steps.headline: Spread the chestnuts in a single layer on baking trays.
steps.description: Use flat trays or drying screens to hold the nuts in place. Avoid stacking or overlapping the chestnuts. If you have room, leave space between each nut to encourage air flow.

steps.headline: Wait 3 to 7 days for the chestnuts to dry.
steps.description: You do need to begin drying the chestnuts a few days before you wish to eat them. The drying time can vary depending on the freshness of the chestnuts and the amount of air exposure they receive. Chestnuts have a high water and starch content, so they dry relatively quickly compared to other nuts.

steps.headline: Squeeze the nuts to test them for hardness.
steps.description: Chestnuts are best before they dry out completely. Test the nuts each day as they dry. When they are at the correct consistency, you will be able to squeeze the shells in about ⁄16 in (0.16 cm). You can then remove the shell from the chestnuts. If the chestnuts harden completely, they will be inedible, so check their consistency often.

steps.headline: Place the chestnuts in a single layer on a dehydrator tray.
steps.description: Pull out the trays in your dehydrator. Load the chestnuts into the trays, taking care not to stack or layer them. Push the trays back into the device to begin the dehydration process. If you do not have enough room for all of your chestnuts, dehydrate them in multiple batches. You can purchase a dehydrator online or at some stores that sell kitchen supplies. If you do not have a dehydrator, you can dry the nuts on a baking tray in the oven. You can also dry the nuts on trays placed near a furnace or radiator.

steps.headline: Set your dehydrator to 100 °F (38 °C).
steps.description: If the nuts are dehydrated at a temperature higher than this, they will lose flavor and not last as long in storage. Keep the temperature at this point the entire time.

steps.headline: Dry the nuts for about 12 hours.
steps.description: This is an average amount of time and can vary depending depending on your dehydrator. Also, fresher chestnuts may take longer to dry. Chestnuts that have been exposed to open air may finish drying sooner than this. Fresh, unshelled chestnuts can take up to 3 days to dry. Shelled chestnuts can take as long as 2 days to dry. Chestnuts should still be edible if they are in the dehydrator longer than they need to be.

steps.headline: Test the chestnuts for hardness.
steps.description: When the chestnuts are dried in low heat, they harden completely. Squeeze the chestnuts to make sure they feel completely hardened. You shouldn’t be able to break them with your fingers.

steps.headline: Soak the chestnuts overnight to reconstitute them before use.
steps.description: When you’re ready to use your chestnuts, set out a bowl of cold water. Submerge the chestnuts for up to 4 to 6 hours. This should soften the nuts again so you can peel off the shells and cook or eat them. Shelled chestnuts may be ready for use after about 1 hour of soaking.

steps.headline: Soak the chestnuts in warm water for 25 minutes.
steps.description: Set out a bowl of water and make sure the chestnuts are submerged in it. This is necessary to do if you are working with raw chestnuts still in their shells, since the water softens them. If you have shelled chestnuts, you do not need to soak them. You can cook them immediately or dry them a different way.

steps.headline: Cut a notch into the shells with a sharp knife.
steps.description: Choose the flattest side of each chestnut. Hold the nut steady and use a sharp knife to make an X. Cut all the way through the hard shell, but avoid cutting into the meat of the nut. Instead of making an X, you can cut each chestnut by making a straight cut along the top side. The cut prevents the nuts from exploding when they are heated at a high temperature.

steps.headline: Lay the chestnuts on a baking sheet.
steps.description: Choose a baking sheet with a rim so the chestnuts don’t spill off. Arrange the nuts on the sheet in a single layer with the cuts facing upwards. Roast the chestnuts in multiple batches as needed.

steps.headline: Roast the chestnuts at 350 °F (177 °C) for 25 minutes.
steps.description: Preheat your oven, then put the baking tray inside. When the chestnuts are done roasting, the shell will curl back from the cut you made earlier. The roasting time needed may vary slightly depending on your oven. Also test the chestnuts by squeezing them once they have cooled. They should feel springy and tender to the touch. You can also boil the chestnuts for 15 minutes in order to soften them.

steps.headline: Peel off the shell and skin by hand.
steps.description: Let the chestnuts cool down until they don’t feel hot enough to burn your hands. Removing the shells is easiest when the chestnuts are warm, so don’t wait too long. Peel away the hard shell first, then take off the soft, papery skin underneath it so only the edible nut is left. Using a paring knife may make this easier. If the nuts cool too much, put them in the microwave for 30 seconds.

steps.headline: Remove any black, moldy, or unopened chestnuts.
steps.description: You will always get a few bad nuts in the bunch. Some chestnuts will prove too stubborn to open and usually aren’t worth eating anyway. Any chestnuts that look off-color can also be unsafe to eat. You can tell when stored chestnuts go bad. They will look black and unpleasant.
